docs.abstract: Start-up implosions don’t matter to most people. But the feelings of unfairness affect us all.

docs.lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.

docs.abstract: The markets going up even as wages stagnate is not a sign of a rigged system.
docs.snippet: The markets going up even as wages stagnate is not a sign of a rigged system.
docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty-two years ago this fall, a new book with the provocative title “Dow 36,000,” by James K. Glassman and Kevin A. Hassett, was published to great fanfare — and not a little derision.

headline.main: Just How High Could the Dow Go?
headline.print_headline: Just How High Could the Dow Go?

docs.abstract: Science can find a cure for our diseases, but not for our societal ills.
docs.snippet: Science can find a cure for our diseases, but not for our societal ills.
docs.lead_paragraph: Back when a viral pandemic killing millions around the world was just the plot of a scary movie, the film “Contagion” was lauded for how accurately it depicted the way such an outbreak would occur.

headline.main: The Unvaccinated May Not Be Who You Think
headline.print_headline: The Unvaccinated May Not Be Who You Think They Are

docs.abstract: Even a tiny bit of gender bias can change the trajectory of a career.
docs.snippet: Even a tiny bit of gender bias can change the trajectory of a career.
docs.lead_paragraph: Even a tiny bit of gender bias can change the trajectory of a career.

headline.main: This Is How Everyday Sexism Could Stop You From Getting That Promotion

byline.original: By Jessica Nordell and Yaryna Serkez

docs.abstract: We asked 18 academics what they would choose if they could pick only one, as Senator Manchin has reportedly advised.
docs.snippet: We asked 18 academics what they would choose if they could pick only one, as Senator Manchin has reportedly advised.
docs.lead_paragraph: The safety net spending bill proposed by Democrats in Congress includes major benefits for families: paid leave, child care, pre-K and child allowances. But as they negotiate over the size of the bill, they may need to choose. Senator Joe Manchin, one of the two centrists whom Democrats must persuade to vote with them, has suggested that they pick just one, Axios reported. In a letter to colleagues Monday night, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi wrote, “Overwhelmingly, the guidance I am receiving from members is to do fewer things well.”

headline.main: Which of These 4 Family Policies Deserves Top Priority?
headline.print_headline: Among the Family Benefits Proposed by the Democrats, Which Deserves Priority?

docs.abstract: The International Monetary Fund says the persistence of the coronavirus and global supply chain crisis weighs on economies.
docs.snippet: The International Monetary Fund says the persistence of the coronavirus and global supply chain crisis weighs on economies.
docs.lead_paragraph: As the world economy struggles to find its footing, the resurgence of the coronavirus and supply chain chokeholds threaten to hold back the global recovery’s momentum, a closely watched report warned on Tuesday.

headline.main: World’s Growth Cools and the Rich-Poor Divide Widens
headline.print_headline: Supply Gridlock and Virus Hinder Global Recovery

byline.original: By Patricia Cohen and Alan Rappeport

docs.abstract: New York City is giving every public school kindergartner $100 in a college savings account. Here’s why every penny matters.
docs.snippet: New York City is giving every public school kindergartner $100 in a college savings account. Here’s why every penny matters.
docs.lead_paragraph: Kindergarten often brings a flood of notices about events, school supplies and class photos. But when Vaniqua Hudson-Figueroa’s daughter started at a public school in Queens, there was one that Ms. Hudson-Figueroa wasn’t expecting: The city had opened a college savings account in her child’s name — and it already had $100 in it.

headline.main: Seeding Accounts for Kindergartners and Hoping to Grow College Graduates
headline.print_headline: New York City Is Giving Every Public School Kindergartner $100 In a College Savings Account.  But It’s About More Than Money.

docs.abstract: Dambisa Moyo has the ear of top business leaders. But there are no simple answers to complex problems.
docs.snippet: Dambisa Moyo has the ear of top business leaders. But there are no simple answers to complex problems.
docs.lead_paragraph: For policymakers and business leaders seeking simple answers to complex problems, Dambisa Moyo is a valuable sounding board. With a Ph.D. in economics from Oxford, a master of public administration from Harvard and experience serving on the boards of companies like Chevron, 3M and Barclays, Ms. Moyo has the kind of broad exposure and macroeconomic knowledge that is often lacking in the upper reaches of siloed organizations.

headline.main: The Zambian Economist at the Crossroads of Global Business
headline.print_headline: At the Crossroads of Global Business

docs.abstract: As the International Monetary Fund gets set for its annual meeting, economists ask if it’s time to update its mandate as the world’s financial crisis responder.
docs.snippet: As the International Monetary Fund gets set for its annual meeting, economists ask if it’s time to update its mandate as the world’s financial crisis responder.
docs.lead_paragraph: Lopsided access to vaccinations, extreme economic inequality, rising food prices and staggering debt are on the agenda when the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank gather for their annual meetings in Washington next week.

headline.main: Debate Looms Over I.M.F.: Should It Do More Than Put Out Fires?
headline.print_headline: I.M.F.’s Role Is the Subject Of Debate

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr LLP

docs.abstract: As Democrats ponder cutting a $3.5 trillion social safety net bill down to perhaps $2 trillion, a proposal to limit programs to the poor has rekindled a debate on the meaning of government itself.
docs.snippet: As Democrats ponder cutting a $3.5 trillion social safety net bill down to perhaps $2 trillion, a proposal to limit programs to the poor has rekindled a debate on the meaning of government itself.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia has a ready retort to fellow Democrats who say shrinking the party’s social safety net bill will mean depriving vulnerable populations of critical resources: Limit access to every program in the ambitious measure to only those Americans who need it most.

headline.main: Benefits for All or Just the Needy? Manchin’s Demand Focuses Debate
headline.print_headline: Democrats’ Dilemma: Lift All, or Just the Needy?

byline.original: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
